name: asymptote-glg-contrib
description: Development tools for the Asymptote vector graphics language.
contribution_justification: https://gitlab.com/thegalagic/asymptote-glg-contrib/-/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
license_location_justification: We follow REUSE Software guidelines for detailing licensing and copyright information. Licenses are stored in the LICENSES dir: https://gitlab.com/thegalagic/asymptote-glg-contrib/-/tree/master/LICENSES
floss_license_justification: The GPL-3.0-or-later license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-3.0-or-later license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
repo_distributed_justification: We use git via GitLab's site.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There have been no publicly known vulnerabilities.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: We detail our process as part of the contribution guide: https://gitlab.com/thegalagic/asymptote-glg-contrib/-/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#vulnerability-reporting-or-security-issues
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: Again, this is detailed in our contribution guide: https://gitlab.com/thegalagic/asymptote-glg-contrib/-/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#vulnerability-reporting-or-security-issues
build_justification: Project does not require building for use as it is at present just a bash script.
tests_documented_added_justification: Our contribution guide states exactly this.
warnings_justification: We use shellcheck for the bash, and the reuse tool to lint for licensing and copyright statements.
warnings_strict_justification: The build fails if our lint checks are not passed.
delivery_unsigned_justification: We don't provide a hash - the project is delivered as source code which GitLab provide securely.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: We have no vulnerabilities to date.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: We have no vulnerabilities to date.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: I believe shellcheck also covers this.
dynamic_analysis_justification: No plans at present to implement this as the tool is solely used by individuals and so they would be attacking themselves.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: We are just a bash script at present so not a memory-unsafe language.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: As above this software is used by individuals therefore it's not relevant to protect them against themselves.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: None have been reported yet but we'll endeavour to meet this criteria in future.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: We do not yet have infrastructure for automatic test runs, but this may be added in future.
discussion_justification: We use GitLab's issue feature.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: Nothing is in the repository currently and we would not intentionally design a build process that relied on credentials stored in the repo.
hardening_justification: It is just a shell script for individual use - we rely on shellcheck to highlight any vulnerabilities. However there may be other avenues by which we can harden against e.g. malicious test fixtures.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers: https://gitlab.com/ conform to these requirements.
installation_common_justification: We have not yet done this, it is a to-do.
build_reproducible_justification: We are using a scripting language presently.
dco_justification: We use a DCO as detailed in our guide: https://gitlab.com/thegalagic/asymptote-glg-contrib/-/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
governance_justification: Our governance (benevolent dictator) is detailed here: https://gitlab.com/thegalagic/asymptote-glg-contrib/-/blob/master/GOVERNANCE.md
code_of_conduct_justification: We use the Contributor Convenant version 2.0 a copy of which is available in the repository: https://gitlab.com/thegalagic/asymptote-glg-contrib/-/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
roles_responsibilities_justification: As we are a single developer at present there is only one "benevolent dictator" who shoulders all responsibilities: https://gitlab.com/thegalagic/asymptote-glg-contrib/-/blob/master/GOVERNANCE.md
access_continuity_justification: We are dependent on one person currently.
bus_factor_justification: We are dependent on one person currently.
documentation_roadmap_justification: We have some to-do's but no dates against them (intentionally).
documentation_architecture_justification: The project is a single bash script and does not warrant such documentation in its present form.
documentation_security_justification: There is more work here for us to document security requirements for a test runner, if any.
documentation_quick_start_justification: I believe the examples at the top of our README are sufficient to cover this: https://gitlab.com/thegalagic/asymptote-glg-contrib/-/blob/master/README.md
documentation_current_justification: The project is brand new so documentation is currently aligned, we'll endeavour to maintain it over time.
documentation_achievements_justification: We'll be adding the badge to our README immediately so it shows on our project page: https://gitlab.com/thegalagic/asymptote-glg-contrib
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: We are a command-line application at present so 'are fairly accessible as-is'. The output is intended to be TAP-compliant which is presumably international. For the project site GitLab themselves promote accessibility testing in their own development (https://docs.gitlab.com/12.10/ee/development/fe_guide/accessibility.html) so presumably their site has no major problems though I could not find verification of that.
internationalization_justification: I will argue N/A on the basis we produce TAP-compliant output and forward through test failures as reported.
sites_password_security_justification: GitLab maintain the site, they are following best-practice.
maintenance_or_update_justification: The project is a single script that can easily be overwritten to upgrade.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: We will when that should arise.
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: This is in our contributing guide: https://gitlab.com/thegalagic/asymptote-glg-contrib/-/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
coding_standards_justification: Shellcheck enforces this for us: https://github.com/koalaman/shellcheck
coding_standards_enforced_justification: It's in the build but as we have no CI yet it is not applied automatically
build_preserve_debug_justification: It's a single shell script at present.
build_repeatable_justification: It's a single shell script at present.
installation_standard_variables_justific: We plan to have an installation process in future.
installation_development_quick_justifica: We list what's required but have no scripted or provided a container setup yet.
external_dependencies_justification: We use git submodules at present: https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Tools-Submodules
dependency_monitoring_justification: We are up-to-date at present but must maintain this in future.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: We can update our dependencies simply with git at present.
interfaces_current_justification: Our tech is simple and up-to-date at present.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: We do not yet have CI setup.
regression_tests_added50_justification: We are a new project so this does not yet apply.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: We do not yet measure our statement coverage.
test_policy_mandated_justification: Our suite is not yet automated it is run on-demand.
implement_secure_design_justification: The software is simple enough that security falls to Linux to ensure we only access what's allowable to a user.
input_validation_justification: We do not process inputs from untrusted sources.
signed_releases_justification: Commits and tags are signed and GitLab show that verification. GitLab make the source code releases available securely.
version_tags_signed_justification: As above we sign each git tag.
contributors_unassociated_justification: We are dependent on one person currently.
copyright_per_file_justification: We follow REUSE software specification and run their lint tool to ensure compliance.
license_per_file_justification: We follow REUSE software specification and run their lint tool to ensure compliance.
small_tasks_justification: We have not yet split our work out into tasks/issues.
require_2FA_justification: Membership to our GitLab group mandates 2FA.
two_person_review_justification: This will not be possible until we have more than one significant contributor.
test_statement_coverage90_justification: Unknown yet if we can measure test coverage but we should find out if we can.
test_branch_coverage80_justification: Unmet for same reason as above.
assurance_case_justification: Along with the above we need to look into this further.

name: Janssen Project
description: The goal of the Janssen Project is to enable organizations to build a scalable centralized authentication and authorization service using free open source software. The components of the project today include implementations of the OAuth, OpenID Connect and FIDO standards. New components may be added as the technology evolves.
description_good_justification: The succinct description is provided on the project home page: https://jans.io
interact_justification: Information about contributing and feedback can be found on https://github.com/JanssenProject/home/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/JanssenProject/home/blob/main/contribute.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/JanssenProject/home/blob/main/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://github.com/JanssenProject/docs
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: All projects are maintained on Github. See https://jans.io for an overview.
repo_distributed_justification: All projects are maintained on Github. See https://jans.io for an overview. Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Each release has a unique semantic version.
version_tags_justification: Git vesion tags are used to indicate releases.
release_notes_justification: Each component has release notes, which are summarized in the project home release notes: https://github.com/JanssenProject/home/blob/main/RELEASE_NOTES.md
release_notes_vulns_justification: Each project has its own release notes which list all publicly known vulnerabilities.
report_tracker_justification: Each project has it's own Github repo. Also see the https://github.com/JanssenProject/home/blob/main/README.md#Support
report_responses_justification: All issues will be addressed within 30 days and updates will be provided periodically.
enhancement_responses_justification: All issues will be addressed within 30 days and updates will be provided periodically.
report_archive_justification: Each inidivdual repository will have it's own Github issues. You can also search the various support channels https://github.com/JanssenProject/home/blob/main/README.md#Support
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: All security issues are responded to within a week.
build_justification: Janssen uses Jenkins to build. The url of the Jenkins server is https://jenkins.jans.io/
build_common_tools_justification: We use Maven to build the software.
build_floss_tools_justification: We use Maven to build the software.
test_justification: Unit tests are available in the Github repos and test results are published for each build on https://jenkins.jans.io/
test_most_justification: We are using unit test frameworks like JUnit and TestNG to write granular tests while using REST API tests for integration testing. Code coverage tools like JaCoCo are used to ensure most of the code is covered by tests.
test_policy_justification: Janssen has policy, formally communicated at https://github.com/JanssenProject/home/blob/main/testing.md
tests_documented_added_justification: Janssen has policy, formally communicated at https://github.com/JanssenProject/home/blob/main/testing.md
warnings_justification: Janssen code quality and static code analysis reports are published at: https://app.codacy.com/gh/JanssenProject/jans-auth-server/dashboard?branch=master
static_analysis_justification: Janssen uses findbugs and Codacy tools as part of CI
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Codacy tool used for static code analysis has vulnerability and security issue analysis capability
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Continuous Integration jobs are hosted at https://jenkins.jans.io
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests. We also have a Google Groups page https://groups.google.com/u/2/g/janssen_project and a Gitter Site: https://gitter.im/JanssenProject/Lobby
english_justification: Each component has it's own Github repository and docs can be found at https://github.com/JanssenProject/docs. A list of components can be found on https://jans.io
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: Tremor Event Processing System
description: Tremor is an early stage event processing and data distribution system designed for large scale production deployments
contribution_justification: https://docs.tremor.rs/Contributing
license_location_justification:
All repositories in the project's github organization have a license in the repository root named 'LICENSE'.
For example: https://github.com/tremor-rs/tremor-runtime/tree/main/LICENSE in the primary repo.
floss_license_justification: The project is primarily released under the Apache Software License https://github.com/tremor-rs/tremor-runtime/tree/main/LICENSE except where otherwise indicated. Portions of the source that derive from other works issued under different compatible licenses are released with modifications under the originating license, and modifications released under the Apache license for continuity The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://docs.tremor.rs/
repo_public_justification: https://github.com/tremor-rs/tremor-runtime.git
repo_track_justification: https://github.com/tremor-rs/tremor-runtime.git
repo_distributed_justification: https://github.com/tremor-rs/tremor-runtime.git
version_unique_justification: The project follows Semantic Versioning (https://semver.org/) format
version_tags_justification: Git tags are used for this purpose. https://github.com/tremor-rs/tremor-runtime/tree/main/docs/development/process/release.md
release_notes_justification:
Release notes are captured in summary form on the releases page on github: https://github.com/tremor-rs/tremor-runtime/releases

A blog article for vX.Y releases is also released with expanded details:

https://www.tremor.rs/blog/2020-10-16-v09-release/
enhancement_responses_justification:
It is up to contributors to submit enhancement requests via the RFC process. https://github.com/tremor-rs/tremor-rfcs
Where enhancements are submitted via PR - the pull request template refers major enhancements to the RFC process. There is also a `needs-rfc` label applied where an rfc is needed but no rfc has been submitted or discussed by the wider community.
report_archive_justification: All requests, reports and responses are gated via the issue tracking system. https://github.com/tremor-rs/tremor-runtime/issues
build_justification: The project's primary code base and repo is based on the rust programming language and the `cargo` based build system can be used for this purpose.
build_common_tools_justification: We use the `cargo` tool from the rust ecosystem for this.
build_floss_tools_justification:
We use github actions for CI/CD which builds on cargo and tremor's own packaged testing tools built as a part of the CI/CD process.

https://github.com/tremor-rs/tremor-runtime/actions
test_justification:
The project uses a combination of unit, functional, benchmark, integration and specialized ( EQC ) tests.

https://docs.tremor.rs/development/testing
test_policy_justification:
We have a formal open RFC policy for all major new functionality.

https://github.com/tremor-rs/tremor-rfcs
warnings_justification: The project enables all warnings and enforces strict / pedantic checks on code style, format. The project includes extra checks and warnings where pedantic clippy ( rust lint tool ) checks were insufficient to our needs that run as part of our CI/CD processes.
crypto_call_justification: The project does not provide bespoke cryptographic protocols, algorithms or methods of its own. The project calls o specifically designed externally provided cryptographic methods.
static_analysis_justification: We integrate cargo clippy and additional strict/pedantic checks as part of the CI/CD process for every change to the project including but not limited to releases.
discussion_justification: The issues feature in every repo and the project slack channel can be used to propose, discuss or index open or historic issues. The primary repositories includes templates for common activities and tasks. The project chat ( slack ) presence can also be used for informal discussion and/or for synchronization with core project maintainers and/or the wider community
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

documentation_interface_justification: External interface is described: https://melexis.github.io/mlx90632-library/group__mlx90632___a_p_i__depends.html API is described  https://melexis.github.io/mlx90632-library/group__mlx90632___a_p_i.html

repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Reviews are done on pull request, unit tests are automatically run as well as static analysis.  Releases are now tagged and monitored through https://github.com/melexis/mlx90632-library/releases
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: It is meant to be used as a submodule to existing projects, so commit hash on master is unique version identifier.
version_semver_justification: It is meant to be used as a submodule to existing projects, so commit hash on master is unique version identifier.
version_tags_justification: It is meant to be used as a submodule to existing projects, so commit hash on master is unique version identifier.
release_notes_justification: GitHub is used to track releases. https://github.com/melexis/mlx90632-library/releases
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No reports filed so far, but we have active maintainer community as well as user base.
build_floss_tools_justification: For building GNU Makefile with GCC or Clang is an option, For unit testing rake (Ruby), Ceedling, CMock and Unity are used.  All tools are open source and its builable.
test_invocation_justification: https://github.com/melexis/mlx90632-library/blob/master/.travis.yml (invoked with each pull request and each build
test_most_justification: Target coverage is 100%, current coverage is 100%.
warnings_justification: common -wall -wpedantic flags for C. Using Coverity Static Analysis tool.
warnings_strict_justification: -Werror is used for non-unit test code.
know_common_errors_justification: https://github.com/Letme Coverity static analysis is implemented to mitigate as much as we can.
delivery_mitm_justification: Delivery is through GitHub ssh or https protocols. Compiled in project on same machine as other code. No binary distribution needed.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: 0 Coverity issues, no other vulnerabilities reported.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: 0 Coverity issues, no other vulnerabilities reported.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Coverity with all settings turned on.
static_analysis_often_justification: Every commit to master is analyzed.
dynamic_analysis_justification: GCov is used in combination of unit tests.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: GCov is used in combination of unit tests.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: Does not use any private credentials. The one to access various services are secure variables in CI.
english_justification: All documentation is in English as that is primary language of the documentation. See https://melexis.github.io/mlx90632-library/
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers. // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: Embedded library - suggested way to include is via submodule.
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: Embedded library, not a software used by other people.
sites_password_security_justification: We do not store any information.
maintenance_or_update_justification: Backward compatiblity so far is ensured through all versions.
build_preserve_debug_justification: Embedded driver library - not linking anything.
installation_development_quick_justifica: Uses Ceedling build system for unit tests which is embedded into Makefile rule directly (so one can only use make). The description of setup (ruby) is also described in README, version of ceedling is linked as submodule to repo itself.
external_dependencies_justification: No external dependencies. There are test buildsystem dependencies as submodules, so that is computer-processable way. https://github.com/melexis/mlx90632-library/blob/master/.gitmodules
dependency_monitoring_justification: Maintainer is subscribed and contributes to Ceedling/Cmock/Unity tools.
